msDesc.head: Composite manuscript of theological and medical texts

summary.seg: This composite manuscript, written for the most part in the first half of the 13th century, has passed through several centuries and several owners, but has spent the majority of its life in East Anglia in the East of England where it remains today. The first quire was most likely a personal notebook or vade mecum: it contains a poem, notes for sermons, and various encyclopedic and theological trivia, as well as a copy of a 1381 letter of introduction from the Prioress and Sisters of Hinchingbrooke Priory (Cambridgeshire) asking the then Bishop of Lincoln John Bokyngham to admit the bearer of the letter, a Walter Sayer of Hook Norton (Oxfordshire) to the title of their house. The rest of the manuscript (Quires 2-17) contains popular medical treatises including the Breviarium of Johannes de Sancto Paulo and the Antidotarium Nicholai, copied by four scribes all working together to produce a useful reference book.

The manuscript belonged to the Augustinian Priory in Barnwell on the outskirts of Cambridge: a brief ownership inscription 'Bernewell' in a fifteenth-century hand can still be seen on f. i verso. The manuscript was almost certainly copied at Barnwell Priory, with several other manuscripts of similar date being known to survive from that house. The book probably remained with the Barnwell community until 1538, when the priory was dissolved during the Reformation. The owners of Add. MS 6865 in the first century following the dissolution of Barnwell Priory are unknown, but the book came into contact with a 16th-century reader, Anthony Shupton, who added his name to the manuscript in several places and who may be the same Anthony Shupton found in London, British Library, Sloane MS 4. By the middle of the 17th century, the book belonged to James Cobbes of Bury St Edmunds, who amassed a collection of manuscripts mostly deriving from East Anglian religious houses. Cobbes passed the book to his grandson, James Harvey, and from there the book passed into the hands of the well-known 18th-century collector Rev. Dr Cox Macro. Macro's collection passed to his daughter, Mary Macro and then through her husband William Stainforth's line to his niece Elizabeth Stainforth and her husband the politician John Patteson. Patteson experienced a period of financial difficulty in the second decade of the 19th century, and sold many family assets, including the Macro manuscripts. They were sold in 1820 by the London book-dealer James Christie the Younger to Dawson Turner, who split his purchase with fellow Norfolk collector Hudson Gurney. This manuscript was one of those that was part of Gurney's portion of purchase, remaining with the Gurney family for a little over a century, until it was sold through Sotheby's by Quintin Edward Gurney in 1936 and purchased by the University Library.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

p.secFol: (2r) Sunt enim sacre scripturae sensus duo

foliation.p: The full foliation sequence for the volume is:
This comprises a mix of 17th- and 20th/21st-century foliation, as follows.

Foliated in the upper outer corner of each recto in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals. Foliated ff. 2-134 by James Cobbes (d. June 1685), a former owner of the manuscript who also added running headings to the upper margins, and a list of the contents on a pasted in piece of paper (f. ii recto at the beginning of the volume. The foliation sequence added by Cobbes is not disrupted by leaves lost at the boundary of Quires 5 and 6, which indicates that those leaves were lost before Cobbes added his foliation sequence.

Additional foliation supplied in several phases by Cambridge University Library staff after the purchase of the volume in March 1936, discussed in the order in which they appear in the manuscript:
The left pastedown foliated as f. i in pencil in the upper left corner of the leaf
The pasted-in paper leaf with Cobbes' list of the contents of the volume foliated as f. ii by Dr James Freeman, Medieval Manuscripts Specialist, Cambridge University Library in 2022.
The first leaf, which lacked an explicit designation by Cobbes, foliated as f. 1 in pencil.
The second of the two leaves designated f. 42 by Cobbes has been refoliated as f. 42a by Dr James Freeman, Medieval Manuscripts Specialist, Cambridge University Library in 2022.
The final leaf, the former right pastedown, has been designated f. iii by Dr James Freeman, Medieval Manuscripts Specialist, Cambridge University Library in 2022.

collation.p:
The manuscript is composite and comprises two parts: the first part is a single-quire unit; the second part contains 16 quires, mostly of 8 leaves.
Quire 114-1 (ff. 1-12; the first leaf a pastedown (f. i verso), the 14th leaf excised) |
Quire 28+1 (ff. 13-21; 1st leaf inserted)
Quires 3-48 (ff. 22-37)
Quire 58-1 (ff. 38-43; 8th leaf missing) (includes duplicated f. 42)
Quire 68-1 (ff. 44-50; 1st leaf missing)
Quires 7-128 (ff. 51-98)
Quire 138 (ff. 99-106; 3rd and 6th leaf are both singletons)
Quires 14-168 (ff. 107-130)
Quire 174 (ff. 131-134)
collation.formula: 114-1 (14th excised) | 210-1 (10th canc.) 3-48 58-1 (8th missing) 68-1 (1st missing) 7-128 138(3rd and 6th singletons) 14-168 174

signatures.p: Alphabetic quire designations (a-r, j omitted) in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. A small '+' added to the lower outer corner of the first recto in the second half of each quire. Quire signatures probably added by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..

note.p: Table of contents (f. ii recto) and running titles (upper margin of each leaf, recto and verso), in a light brown ink, by the hand of James Cobbes (b. ?1602, d. 1685) Cobb(e)s, James (b. ?1602 d. 1685) .

binding.p: Medieval binding. Full bound in tawed skin over bevelled-edge wood boards cut flush with the book-block. Five sewing supports of split tawed skin laced into the boards horizontally and secured in place with wood pegs. Covers have an impressed repeating pattern as if wrapped by a thin cord for a significant period of time. Head and tail bands sewn in a neutral cream yarn and anchored through the tawed skin cover at the spine openings. Hook-and-bar fastening in the centre of the fore edge: tawed skin strap embedded in the fore edge of the left board, the free end terminating in a decorative metal hook; metal bar fastening embedded in the fore edge of the right board. Faint traces of spotted design painted onto head, fore, and tail edges of the bookblock.

Two paper labels fixed to the spine with text handwritten in ink: upper label almost entirely gone; lower label '29'. Spine labels added while the manuscript was in the possession of Dr Cox Macro and reflect his library designations.

Left pastedown f. i is parchment and conjoint with the last leaf of the first quire (now cancelled). Left pastedown contains:
- Current shelfmark in ink 'Add. 6865'
- The letter 'E' - a size classification used by Cambridge University Library
- Medieval ownership inscription: 'Bernewell'
- A note in ink recording the purchase of the manuscript by Cambridge University Library by the hand of Alwyn Faber Scholfield (b. 1884, d. 1969) Scholfield, A. F. (Alwyn Faber), 1884-1969, University Librarian 1923-1949
- A paper leaf pasted onto the pastedown along the paper leaf's left edge containing a list of the contents of the volume by James Cobbes. The paper leaf has the separate designation ii.

Former right pastedown is parchment and has been lifted and is now foliated as f. iii. What is now the recto, f. iii recto, contains the name 'Anthony Shupton' twice in ink, and some pen trials, also in ink.
Medieval sewn repairs to the turn ins on the right board.
Head and fore edge of book-block decorated with red (and blue?) dot pattern.

provenance.p: Owned by the Augustinian Priory of St Giles and St AndrewBarnwell Priory (Cambridge, England) in Barnwell, Cambridge. The name 'Bernewell' is written in ink on f. i verso in a medieval hand. The book seems to have been in the possession of a member of the Barnwell community in 1451: on f. 13r, there is an erased inscription printed by J.S. Ringrose in her Summary Catalogue of the Additional Manuscripts: Hic liber pertinet domui canonicorum de Bernwell [...] domino Willelmo Teb[...] canonico eiusdem domus [...] die Octobris Anno Domini 1451. As Ringrose points out, this is probably William Tebbald Tebbald, William, who was Prior of Barnwell from 26 Nov 1474 until his death on 6 August 1489.

The name Anthony Shupton Shupton, Anthony appears on ff. 14r, 134v, and iii recto. This appears to be the same Anthony Shupton who added his name in several places to London, British Library, Sloane MS 4. Evidence in the Sloane manuscript suggests that Shupton was alive in 1510, but the dates of his birth and death are unknown.

Owned by James Cobbes (b. ?1602, d. 1685) Cobb(e)s, James (b. ?1602 d. 1685) of Bury St Edmunds, who owned several manuscripts that had once belonged to the Abbey in Bury St Edmunds. Cobbes foliated the manuscript and added running titles to the centre of the upper margin of each leaf, as well as a table of contents on f. ii recto.
For further information about Cobbes as a collector see Beadle (2004).

listBibl.bibl: R. Beadle, 'The manuscripts of James Cobbes of Bury St Edmunds (c. 1602-1685)' in T. Matsuda, R. A. Linethal, J. Scahill (eds.), The medieval book and a modern collector: essays in honour of Toshiyuki Takamiya (Cambridge, 2004), pp. 427-442

provenance.p: In his will, James Cobbes (b. ?1602, d. 1685) Cobb(e)s, James (b. ?1602 d. 1685) left his Bookes and papers concerning Literature to his grandchild, James Harvy Harv(e)y, James. Several items that passed from James Cobbes to James Harvy eventually became part of the collection of Rev. Dr Cox Macro (b. 1683, d. 2 Feb 1767) Macro, Cox, b. 1683, d. 2 Feb 1767.
For further information about Cobbes as a collector see Beadle (2004).

Owned by Rev. Dr Cox Macro (b. 1683, d. 2 Feb 1767) Macro, Cox, b. 1683, d. 2 Feb 1767 of Bury St Edmunds. Macro probably purchased the volume from James Cobbes' grandson James Harvy as several Cobbes manuscripts became part of Macro's collection.

Cambridge, University Library, Add. MS 6865 was manuscript was no. 29 in Cox Macro's library and a label with that designation is still present on the spine, as is his former title label, now mostly torn away. The manuscript was seen among the items in Macro's library by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) Tanner, Thomas, 1674-1735 and appears among Macro's possessions in Tanner's Bibliotheca Britannico-Hibernica published in 1748.
For further information about Macro's collection see Beadle (2004) and (2016).

listBibl.bibl: R. Beadle, 'Macro MS 5: A Historical Reconstruction', Transactions of the Cambridge Bibliographical Society 16.1 (2016), pp. 35-77

provenance.p: After Dr Cox Macro's death, his library passed to his daughter, Mary Macro Macro, Mary . Mary Macro married William Stainforth Stainforth, William in 1767. After their deaths, the manuscripts passed to William Stainforth's niece Elizabeth Stainforth (b. 1760) Stainforth, Elizabeth (b. 1760) . She married John Patteson (b. 1755, d. 1833) Patteson, John, 1755-1833 who owned the manuscripts until 1820.
For further information about Macro's collection see Beadle (2016).

John Patteson Patteson, John, 1755-1833 encountered financial difficulties in the second decade of the 19th century, and in 1820 he sold the Macro manuscripts to London bookseller James Christie (b. 1773, d. 1831) Christie, James, 1773-1831 .
For further information about Macro's collection see Beadle (2016).

The Macro manuscripts were purchased as a group from James Christie the Younger (b. 1773, d. 1831) Christie, James, 1773-1831 by Dawson Turner (b. 1775, d. 1858) Turner, Dawson, 1775-1858 on the understanding that fellow collector Hudson Gurney would later purchase a portion of the collection.
For further information about Macro's collection see Beadle (2016).

Purchased from Dawson Turner Turner, Dawson, 1775-1858 by Hudson Gurney (b. 1775, d. 1864) Gurney, Hudson, 1775-1864 of Bawdeswell Hall, Bawdeswell, Norfolk. The manuscript remained with the Gurney family until it was sold by Major Quintin Edward Gurney (b. 1883, d. 1968) Gurney, Q. E. (Quintin Edward), 1883-1968 in a sale of the Gurney family manuscripts at Sotheby's in 1936.
For further information about Macro's collection see Beadle (2016).

history.acquisition: Purchased in the Gurney sale (Sotheby's) on 30 March 1936, lot 153, with funds from the Wilson-Barkworth benefaction.

source.p: This catalogue entry draws on Jayne Ringrose, Summary Catalogue of the Additional Medieval Manuscripts in Cambridge University Library acquired before 1940 (Woodbridge, 2009), by kind permission of the Boydell Press.

This catalogue entry also draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1948 and 1970 by H.L. Pink Pink, H. L., now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/75) and also available as a (digitised scan).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

series.title: Edizione nazionale dei testi mediolatini d'Italia

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 6865, ff. 1-12

msItem.title: Stans puer ad mensam [Latin]
msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.incipit: 1r Stans puer ad mensam domini bona dogmata discat
msItem.explicit: 1v Hoc penitus caveas ne sociis noceas
msItem.note: Printed (pp. 61-62) and given the designation 'C' in Gieben, 'Robert Grosseteste and Medieval Courtesy-Books'. This recension stands slightly apart from the other known versions of the poem, but contains the lines of the 'short version' of the poem and includes the line 'Hec qui me docuit grossum caput est sibi nomen' (ln 27 in this manuscript according to Gieben's arrangement of the text).

listBibl.bibl: S. Harrison Thomson, The Writings of Robert Grosseteste Bishop of Lincoln 1235-53 (Cambridge, 1940), pp. 149-150
S. Gieben, 'Robert Grosseteste and Medieval Courtesy Books', Vivarium, 5.1, pp. 47-74

msItem.title: Grammatical mnemonics and notes in verse and prose on theological matters
msItem.explicit: 2r Sapientia dicitur quasi sapida scientia . et est de diuinis . Prudencia non de humanis . Animaduertite .i. ad animad
msItem.note: Text is copied in the margins and blank spaces of f. 1r, including a portion of text copied upside down. Text continues onto f. 1v and into the upper and lower margins of f. 2r.

msItem.title: De varietate sensuum sacrae scripturae
msItem.incipit: 2r Sunt enim sacre scripture sensus duo
msItem.explicit: 2v Sed beda super tabernaculum aliter distinguit

msItem.title: Copy of a letter from the Prioress and Sisters of St James without Huntingdon (Hinchningbrooke Priory), to John Bokyngham, Bishop of Lincoln
msItem.author: Prioress and Sisters of St James without Huntingdon

note.p: Copy of a letter from the Prioress (?Joan Tichmersh) and Sisters of St James without Huntingdon (Hinchingbrooke Priory), Huntingdon to John Bokyngham (d. ?1399) Johannes Bockinghamus d. ?1399 , bishop of Lincoln, presenting the bearer, Walter Sayer of Hook Norton (Oxfordshire), for admission by ordination to the title of their house. The letter is dated 4 kal. March, 1380, (perhaps 27 Feb 1381), which is a terminus post quem for this copy of the letter.

msItem.title: Notes for 14 sermons
msItem.incipit: 3r Dic ut lapides isti panes fiant

msItem.title: Miscellaneous notes including notes on metaphysics
msItem.note: Contains five lines from the Sentences of the Four Philosophers on the degeneracy of the times.

p.secFol: 2r Sunt enim sacre scripturae sensus duo

collation.p: One quire, originally of 14 leaves, now 12. The first leaf is now the left pastedown and has the foliation f. i. The original 14th leaf has been cut away and only a stub remains.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves are stained. Some text lost to rubbing. The first leaf (f. 1) torn in half vertically and repaired with a running stitch in a neutral-cream yarn; repair is probably medieval.

layout.seg: Ruled predominantly in two-column format frame and lines; 40 lines to the column, vertical lines ruled in ink, horizontal lines ruled in leadpoint. Written above top line. Written in unruled single-column format ff. 1rv, 12v, and the lower portions of 11v-12r.

handNote.p: Written in northern textualis libraria with anglicana features.

origin.origPlace: England, probably the Augustinian Priory in Barnwell, Cambridgeshire.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge University Library, Add. MS 6865, ff. 13-134

msItem.title: Preface to the Breviarium
msItem.author: Johannes de Sancto Paulo
msItem.rubric: 14r Incipit breuiarius a magistro iohanne de sancto paulo editus
msItem.incipit: 14r Assiduis peticionibus me karissimi compendiose morborum signum
msItem.explicit: 14r et scie manuum . et pedum uinta uero de febribus

msItem.title: Breviarium
msItem.author: Johannes de Sancto Paulo
msItem.rubric: 14r Incipit liber de generalibus signis et causis egri
msItem.explicit: 60r Uos secundum scripta ista operamini . urina opera dirigente deo omnipotente
msItem.note: Gap in text between Book 2, 'De lapide' (ends imperfectly, 'oleo laurino pulegio', on f. 43v) and Book 3, 'De gonorea' (begins imperfectly, 'et litargiro lamina', on f. 44r).

msItem.title: Antidotarium Nicholai
msItem.author: Nicholas
msItem.incipit: 61r Ego Nicolaus rogatus a quibusdam in practica medicine
msItem.note: Preceded on ff. 60v-61r by a list of antidotes.
Attributed to Nicholas of Hostresham Nicolaus de Hostresham in the manuscript.

msItem.title: Synonima Antidotarii Nicolai
msItem.explicit: 81r Zucozaria id est agnus castus uel salices

msItem.title: De passionibus
msItem.incipit: 81v Caput multis passionibus diuersisque humoribus uel in existentibus

msItem.title: Treatise on obstetrics and gynaecology
msItem.incipit: 103v Matrix ad humanam generationem membrum maxime multis subiacens passionibus

msItem.title: Treatise on sciatic pain
msItem.explicit: 107v uinum limphatum et subtile bibant et cetera

msItem.title: Treatise on stomach pain
msItem.incipit: 107v Cum sit stomachus pro nature necessitate
msItem.explicit: 108r et sepius humanum corpus molestant insequimur

msItem.title: Treatise on the preparation of medicines
msItem.rubric: 116r Incipit tractatus de aquis . sirupis . clisteribus et oleis suppositoriis . pessariis s.m.p.d.m. et de syringis
msItem.explicit: 133r et ista sufficiant de pessariis et finita sunt . amen

msItem.title: Medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: Written in several hands of the 13th and 14th centuries.

list.item: Quire 58-1 (8th missing; ff. 38-43 (includes f. 42 and f. 42a))
Quire 138 (3rd bifolium - 3rd and 6th leaves) - formed of two singletons; ff. 99-106)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords present in the lower inner corner of the final versos of Quires 4, 7, 8, 9.

supportDesc.condition: Trimmed for binding with loss of some catchwords and all medieval quire and leaf signatures. Some leaves stained with marks from objects (e.g., the opening ff. 66v-67r) or splashes of various liquids.

layout.seg: Ruled in light brown ink, frame and lines, typically 37 lines to the column. Written in two-column format above top line. The final leaf, f. 134rv is unruled and is written in single-column format.

handNote.p: Folios 14r-60r written in a late English protogothic minuscule by Scribe 1 of Part 2 of this manuscript.
Folios 60v-61r written in a late English protogothic minuscule by Scribe 2 of Part 2 of this manuscript.
Folios 61v-81r written in a late English protogothic minuscule by Scribe 3 of Part 2 of this manuscript.
Folios 81v-133v written in a late English protogothic minuscule by Scribe 4 of Part 2 of this manuscript.
Medical recipes added to ff. 13rv and 134rv in a northern textualis libraria characterised by long ascenders and descenders with a backward-leaning terminal flick.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials of the 'Arabesque' type, several lines high at the major divisions of the text; red initials with minor decorative elements sometimes added in yellow.

decoDesc.decoNote: Plain red initials for lemma in glossaries and lists of contents and for some minor divisions of the texts.

decoNote.p: Rubrication (red only) for titles of texts and headings to some major and minor divisions of the texts.

note.p: Oval Cambridge University Library ownership stamp in red ink on the following leaves: 14r, 134r.
Note on f. 60v in the hand of James Cobbes James Cobb(e)s (b. ?1602 d. 1685) in which he records his (incorrect) belief that several texts in the manuscript are the works of a Nicholas of Hostresham.

origin.origPlace: England, probably the Augustinian Priory in Barnwell, Cambridgeshire.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
